awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Flow-aided aerial vehicle navigation and control
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this I-Corps project is the development of technology to extend battery life in unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs). Small unmanned aerial vehicles have been utilized in a wide range of fields, including aerophotography, delivery, surveying, and surveillance in confined spaces. However, the utilization and duration of flight of small UAVs is often limited by the allowed on-board battery capacity, especially in extreme windy conditions when UAVs need to make extra effort to reject disturbances and remain robust.  The proposed technology solves the UAV navigation and control problems in turbulence by traversing turbulent flows using minimal time and energy. The new technology may enable more UAVs to operate in conditions beyond their current capabilities and could make UAVs more commercially viable.  In addition, the new product fits well with the current trend towards convenient, contact-free, autonomous drone delivery services. The development of efficient UAV navigation and control strategies in wind may benefit the drone delivery industry in the future.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of energy-harvesting control algorithms to extend battery life in unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs). Inspired by principles from particle transport theory in fluid dynamics, the proposed technology provides intelligent control algorithms that enable the aerial vehicle to leverage beneficial flow structures, such as turbulent eddies, rising thermals, and tailwinds, and navigate in highly turbulent environments with significantly less expenditure of time and energy. An implicit model following (IMF) controller was developed to make the aerial vehicle follow the dynamic behavior of settling inertial particles undergoing the fast-tracking effect and extract energy from turbulent flows. Given on-board flow measurements, the controlled aerial vehicle tends to travel under advantageous tailwinds more often, while avoiding adverse headwinds autonomously. Compared to existing control techniques, the innovation of this technology is that prior knowledge of the exact flow parametric model is not required, and controlled aerial vehicles may harvest energy from wind gusts instead of using battery power to compensate for external wind disturbances.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This multi-disciplinary i-Corps project explores the business and commercialization opportunities of the micro-drone concept called GoFly, a novel concept in flight control for small-scale vehicles inspired by nature and bird soaring. The new control design developed in the student thesis leverages particle transport theory from fluid dynamics and multivariable control theory on implicit model following to develop a flow sustained methods for flying through turbulent flow, as observed in nature in bird flight.

The team explored application opportunities by interviewing flight control engineers at drone companies who need to perform flight tasks in high winds of more than 30 mph, our technology provides control algorithms that help to harvest energy from wind gusts and extend the duration of flight by 30%.The initial idea for commercialization impinged on last-mile drone and recreational drone manufacturers. The initial value proposition was thought by the team to be the ability to extend flight endurance, save energy, and deliver more packages.  After the interview process was conducted, the team determined that a better and related value proposition would be to help customers such as WaveAerospace to enable first responders to be on scene faster, stay longer, search larger areas, and carry much more in any weather. The subject experts offered the team many useful insights that helped them pivot their focus of primary customer segments.
Further analysis of the market and business value allowed the team to come to the conclusion that the product-market fit is not yet clear enough to yield a final decision. In the last months of the grant, the team further validated the novel flight controller in computer simulations for a fixed-wing aircraft. It was found that further technical research might be needed, including experimental validation, in order to convince manufacturers to implement their controller on real drones. In fact, the team learned from the interviews that, in the drone industry where technology is rapidly evolving on a constant basis, customers must see the product in action before they move from the interest stage to the consideration stage. The team leader then proceeded to spend his last semester enrolled in an entrepreneurial program at Cornell to work more closely with MBA students and a personal mentor on further identifying potential market opportunities and to develop a possible business plan for scaling up and going to market. This period was also used to investigate other important applications of the novel control design spanning neuroscience and neuroengineering.
